query: Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
url2text: Chipmaker Broadcom has made an unsolicited bid to buy rival Qualcomm for $130 billion. If the deal is accepted it will be the biggest ever takeover in the technology sector, following a run of billion-dollar consolidation deals in the semiconductor industry.

Broadcom president and CEO Hock Tan said the bid is “compelling for stockholders and stakeholders in both companies,” with the combined company able to operate at a larger scale across more product ranges.
“We would not make this offer if we were not confident that our common global customers would embrace the proposed combination,” said Tan in a press statement.
Broadcom is offering a combination cash-and-stock deal of $70 per share for Qualcomm, representing a 28 percent premium over the closing price of Qualcomm’s stock on November 2nd.
The $130 billion offer includes $25 billion in assumed debt.
If Tan can convince Qualcomm’s board of the deal’s merits, the new firm would become the world’s third-largest chipmaker, behind Intel and Samsung.

The bid has been carefully timed. Broadcom’s shares have risen 60 percent over the past year, while Qualcomm’s have faltered as the company’s revenues are threatened by a legal battle with Apple over alleged anti-competitive behavior.
As of last Friday, Qualcomm’s market capitalization was $91 billion while Broadcom’s stood at $112 billion.
The share price of both firms rose last week as rumors of the bid spread.
The proposed deal is a significant milestone for the $300 billion semiconductor industry, which has been gripped in recent years by a mania of mergers and acquisitions.
These include Softbank’s $31 billion purchase of chip designer ARM, Intel’s $16.7 billion acquisition of Altera, and an ongoing attempt by Qualcomm itself to buy NXP Semiconductors for $39 billion.

These moves have been motivated by high-level shifts in modern tech. Computing power has migrated from PCs to smartphones and, while faster mobile data networks promise to bring more internet-connected devices online — from self-driving cars to smart washing machines.

Broadcom’s bid for Qualcomm seems intended to plug a gap in the former’s product portfolio. The California-based Broadcom provides designs for Wi-Fi and Bluetooth chips, as well as industrial infrastructure products, but is missing hardware that can take advantage of the spread of 4G and 5G networks.
“Broadcom needs LTE and 5G capability that they don't have today,” said Moor Insights & Strategy analyst Patrick Moorhead told the Financial Times.
“That’s what this comes down to. What comes with it, though, is a ton of complexity.”
That complexity includes Qualcomm’s legal troubles and the chipmaker’s bid to buy NXP Semiconductors.
That deal is undergoing regulatory scrutiny in Europe as well as objections from NXP shareholders, who say the company has been undervalued.
On top of this, if Qualcomm does accept Broadcom’s offer, the deal would almost certainly attract the attention of America’s own regulators.

query: Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
url2text: U.S. district judge Lucy Koh has ruled that some of Qualcomm’s practices to beat competitors in the smartphone chip market violated antitrust laws.

Judge Koh has sided with the Federal Trade Commission’s (FTC) allegations that Qualcomm charged unreasonably high royalties for its patents, which has “strangled competition” and “harmed rivals, OEMs, and end consumers in the process,” she said in her ruling.
In a statement, Qualcomm said it would “immediately seek a stay of the district court’s judgment and an expedited appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit.”
“We strongly disagree with the judge’s conclusions, her interpretation of the facts and her application of the law,” Don Rosenberg, EVP and general counsel of Qualcomm, said.

The FTC brought a suit against Qualcomm in January 2017, accusing the chipmaker of using anti-competitive tactics to “maintain its monopoly” as the dominant vendor of semiconductors for phones and other mobile gadgets.
The allegations include entering into exclusive agreements with smartphone makers and refusing to sell its standard-essential patents to competitors.
RELATED: FTC's suit against Qualcomm to proceed after judge denies move to dismiss
Qualcomm filed to dismiss the FTC’s charges in April 2017. The request was heard by Judge Koh, who ruled against the company and allowed the FTC to pursue the complaint.
The FTC’s allegations are similar to those brought by Apple against Qualcomm in 2017. Apple accused Qualcomm of charging high royalties rates and refusing to license patents to other chipmakers.
Apple alleged Qualcomm also refused to supply chips to Apple in 2018, which caused the phone maker to rely exclusively on Intel for iPhone XS, iPhone XS Max and the iPhone XR.
Apple was forced to settle with Qualcomm about a month ago, as Intel’s 5G modem chips began to slip behind schedule.
Apple agreed to pay its high royalty rates in order to have access to Qualcomm’s 5G modems.
RELATED: Qualcomm and Apple abruptly drop all litigation

In Judge Koh’s most recent ruling, she has asked Qualcomm to renegotiate its licensing agreements with customers without relying on what she called “unfair tactics,” such as threatening to cut off access to chips.
She also ruled that Qualcomm cannot enter into exclusive agreements with smartphone makers.

query: Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
url2text: The head of Intel's Korean unit has underestimated its biggest rival Qualcomm's chip-making technology by insisting that Intel is ahead of it in terms of technology and market response.

The country manager Lee Hee-sung stressed that it's becoming aggressive in persuading major Korean handset vendors, such as Samsung Electronics, LG Electronics and Pantech, to introduce mobile devices using Intel processors.
It's uncommon for the U.S.-based semiconductor giant to talk about its rivals. Lee, who is one of the longest-serving CEOs of a foreign firm in Korea, is known to be a very outspoken person.
It remains uncertain whether Intel can steal as much stakes as it wants from Qualcomm as the California-headquartered Intel is truly late in the market for processors.
"Intel is a semiconductor company that has dual strengths in development and manufacturing. Our fourth-generation Haswell-branded System-on-Chip (SoC) has advantages in power consumption.
This is the best example that shows Intel's merits," Lee recently told reporters in Seoul.
The executive said he always discusses with those Korean tech companies for the wider usage of the Intel chips.
He is indifferent about the fact that Intel's future is dependent upon the Samsung Galaxy Tab 3.

Samsung has recently marketed the Tab 3 using Intel processors, a move seen by many analysts and officials as one of the remarkable achievements struck by Intel to better power its processor business.

The Tab 3 will be available in the United States via top mobile carriers. As Samsung is investing heavily to increase its stakes in the U.S. tablet market, the two firms are expected to launch aggressive promotional campaigns.

The success of the new Intel processor is more than significant for the American company, which is facing uncertain market conditions due to a decline in conventional PC sales, to strengthen its presence in the growing tablet market.

A leading market research firm IHS iSuppli revealed that Intel grabbed a negligible 5 percent share of the market for digital baseband and applications processors used in smartphones and other connected mobile devices last year.

Specifically, sales of netbooks, a product Intel still dominated with its Atom family of low-end and unprofitable processors, have been badly impacted by the downturn in the PC market as well as the growth in the media tablet, said Samsung officials.
Intel faces a growing challenge from Qualcomm, which holds a market share in the mobile phone semiconductor business, seven times larger than Intel's.
Driven by such confidence, Lee hinted of twisting Samsung's supply chain management structure that has so far been powered by Qualcomm.
"Our new CEO Brian Krzanich is inspecting Intel's global offices with the board chairman Renee James.
Because meeting with our clients is important, James had a meeting with Samsung's co-CEO Shin Jong-kyun in Seoul, last week," Lee said.
He continued; "The meeting with Samsung signifies that Intel recognizes the Korean company as one of its crucial business partners."
Samsung sources said the issue of how to supply Intel chips to upcoming Samsung devices was on the table.
A Samsung spokesman declined to confirm the meeting, itself.
Qualcomm spokesman S.S. Kim also refused comments, although industry watchers and officials claim that the meeting was upsetting Qualcomm.
Samsung is using its Exynos-branded processors in the Galaxy line of devices, while Qualcomm has been providing its Snapdragon processors to the world's biggest smartphone manufacturer.

query: Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
url2text: Qualcomm helped create the smartphone as we know it. Its patents are part of the standard for modern wireless broadband systems, and the company is now the world’s largest producer of baseband processors — the modem chip that lets phones connect to data networks.
But over the next few weeks, a judge will determine whether Qualcomm abused that power, hearing a complaint brought by the Federal Trade Commission in 2017.

The Qualcomm trial started on January 4th, and it will run through January 28th. After that, Judge Lucy Koh — the California district judge who presided over Apple and Samsung’s massive patent infringement trial — will have to decide whether Qualcomm unfairly monopolized the baseband processor market.
Here’s why the case matters to Qualcomm, the FTC, and everyone who owns a phone.
The FTC claims Qualcomm has engaged in monopolistic practices that lock out potential competitors and make phones more expensive for consumers.
The complaint includes a few different, but related, accusations:
- Qualcomm won’t sell baseband processors to phone makers unless they agree to “disproportionately high” patent royalties, a policy referred to as “no license — no chips.”
- Qualcomm unfairly refuses to license essential patents to other chipmakers, which prevents competitors from challenging its dominance.
- Qualcomm offered Apple lower patent royalties if the iPhone exclusively used Qualcomm chips, locking competitors like Intel out of an incredibly popular phone.
This allegedly stopped Apple from offering the iPhone on Sprint’s WiMAX network — which offered speeds faster than other networks’ 3G systems, but was supported by Intel.

The FTC says these behaviors are all anti-competitive, and that because Qualcomm’s patents are part of an official industry standard, they also violate a requirement to license the patents on fair, reasonable, and nondiscriminatory (FRAND) terms.

Qualcomm has denied these claims. It contends that the FTC’s complaint is “based on a flawed legal theory, a lack of economic support, and significant misconceptions about the mobile technology industry,” and that “Qualcomm has never withheld or threatened to withhold chip supply in order to obtain agreement to unfair or unreasonable licensing terms.”
Qualcomm arguably holds what FOSSPatents writer Florian Mueller has described as “mutually reinforcing monopolies” — one on wireless broadband modems, and another on certain patents.
A 2018 analyst report estimated Qualcomm had a 52 percent share of the baseband processor market, with competitors Samsung and MediaTek trailing far behind.
It also owns patents that are vital to wireless broadband, so any device with a high-speed mobile data connection generates royalties for Qualcomm.
As phone makers start building their first 5G-enabled products, Qualcomm and other modem providers will be vying for that new market as well — and, unsurprisingly, Qualcomm is poised to dominate it.

If Qualcomm is indeed operating a monopoly, that could drive up the price of any 5G device. And with companies touting 5G as a viable internet option for laptops as well as phones, it would affect a broad swathe of products.

The FTC racked up one victory last year: in November, Judge Koh ruled that rival chipmakers should be able to directly license Qualcomm’s patents, based on the rules around standard-essential patents.

The actual trial, however, started on January 4th. The first day saw testimony from Huawei and Lenovo, both of which contended that Qualcomm had threatened to withhold chips unless they signed a licensing deal.

“Qualcomm has in the past retaliated against customers who have attempted to challenge its legal terms by either delaying, or cutting off supply of chips,” said Lenovo intellectual property vice president Ira Blumberg.
“We don’t know if Qualcomm would follow through on their threat to cut off supply, but we can’t take that risk.”
Several other countries have already fined Qualcomm for anti-competitive behavior. China ordered it to pay around $975 million in 2015, and South Korea imposed a roughly $854 million fine in 2016.
In January of 2018, the European Union fined it $1.2 billion for cutting exclusivity deals with Apple.
And Qualcomm settled a $774 million fine from Taiwan in mid-2018, paying a reduced amount and agreeing to help launch the country’s 5G network.

But Qualcomm’s most high-profile legal headache is Apple. Apple sued Qualcomm three days after the FTC filed its complaint, making several of the same accusations about inflated prices and “no license, no chip” policies.
It also claimed that Qualcomm had withheld a $1 billion royalty refund because Apple had cooperated with Korean antitrust regulators during the agency’s investigation.
(Apple used Qualcomm chips for years, but it’s switching to Intel ones for newer phones.)
Qualcomm also has several of its own lawsuits pending against Apple. It’s accused Apple of patent infringement in China and Germany, where it’s had some success getting older iPhone models banned.
And last fall, it claimed to have found documents proving Apple secretly shared Qualcomm code with Intel to speed up its modems.
The companies discussed settling, but last month, a judge officially scheduled that trial for April 15th.
Intel and Samsung both filed amicus briefs supporting the FTC in 2017. (Both of these companies are direct competitors, and Samsung is a phone manufacturer as well.)
Intel accused Qualcomm of running an “interlocking web of abusive patent and commercial practices” that prevented companies from buying other companies’ chips.
Samsung also complained that it couldn’t sell its Exynos chips to other phone manufacturers, due to Qualcomm’s exclusionary licensing policies.
The app company industry group ACT (formerly known as the Association for Competitive Technology) filed a brief supporting the FTC’s push for more strictly enforced FRAND rules.
Conversely, Nokia submitted one in favor of Qualcomm — arguing that companies shouldn’t have to license essential patents to competitors.
The FTC is demanding that Qualcomm stop the practices described above, and like regulators in other countries, it could impose a fine.
And this trial’s verdict will likely influence the outcome of Apple’s case against Qualcomm — or convince the two companies to settle that particular suit.

Qualcomm announced last year that it would set a lower cap for the maximum royalty cost per phone, and it’s licensing 5G technology at a lower rate than earlier patents, partly in an apparent attempt to prevent more disputes with its customers.
If the courts rule in the FTC’s favor, that could make the company even more cautious about drawing future lawsuits.
More broadly, this case will affect any future dispute between two companies over essential patents.

Qualcomm has argued that the FTC is trying to “hobble a quintessential American technology company” while opening the door for foreign companies to take over the 5G hardware market, “stifling innovation just when it’s needed most.”
Alternately, an antitrust ruling could create stronger competition between chipmakers and bring down prices, just as the industry is moving into a new generation of mobile broadband.
If prices drop and more competitors emerge, as the FTC suggests, that doesn’t mean individual customers will see huge discounts.

(Even at the high end, Qualcomm says its royalties top out at $20 per phone.) But it could change how manufacturers approach building the phones we use, letting them spend more money on other features — or help other chipmakers succeed with potentially groundbreaking new designs.
Update January 10th, 1:00PM ET: Updated the price of phone royalties with detail provided by Qualcomm.

query: Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
url2text: On May 21, U.S. District Judge Lucy Koh ruled that Qualcomm used its monopoly power to coerce companies into paying “unreasonably high” royalties on Qualcomm’s wireless inventions.

In particular, Qualcomm’s practice of requiring handset makers such as Apple and Samsung to sign a patent license agreement before the handset maker could purchase their modem chips was deemed anticompetitive (the “no license/no chip” policy).

Qualcomm’s share-based rebates, in which Qualcomm required certain customers such as LG Electronics and Samsung to buy a percentage of its total chip from Qualcomm as a condition of getting a rebate (typically 85 percent), and Qualcomm’s exclusive deal with Apple (which also involved rebates on the royalty rate) also were deemed anticompetitive.

In addition to violating its fair, reasonable, and non-discriminatory (“FRAND”) commitments, the district court decision held that Qualcomm has an antitrust duty to license its standard essential patents (“SEPs”) to rival chip suppliers such as Intel and MediaTek.

Judge Koh ordered Qualcomm to renegotiate its deals with customers and enter into new deals with rival chip makers such as Intel, and to submit to arbitration of what is a fair and reasonable royalty.
Judge Koh’s decision in the FTC’s case against Qualcomm came on the heels of a settlement between Qualcomm and Apple.
Apple’s lawsuit challenged much of the same conduct as the FTC’s case.
The Qualcomm decision could be one of the most significant antitrust cases, and it has drawn commentary from all corners.

Before the ruling, the Department of Justice intervened with a request for an evidentiary hearing on remedies—warning that an overly broad remedy could stifle innovation—a request that was not heeded by Judge Koh.

The FTC Staff filed a response to DOJ’s Statement, indicating that the focus of DOJ’s Statement was misplaced because evidence of remedy already has been considered and the trial court already decided not to consider remedy separately.

And FTC Commissioner Christine Wilson penned an op-ed in the Wall Street Journal criticizing the decision, echoing many of the same concerns expressed by Commissioner Maureen Ohlhausen when the FTC initially filed the suit.
Does the decision represent a victory for customer-facing tech platforms in their dealings with input providers?
Could it threaten innovation or certain pricing models, as some scholars have claimed? And if so, which firms in the U.S. economy are most vulnerable to new antitrust liability?
To answer those questions, we invited Jonathan Barnett of USC’s Gould School of Law, Stanford Law School’s Doug Melamed, and Fiona Scott Morton of Yale’s School of Management to a Bytes Chat.
The Chat was moderated by Hal Singer, editor of Washington Bytes and Senior Fellow of the George Washington Institute of Public Policy.
The transcript was edited lightly for readability, and each contributor had the opportunity to refine answers and add hyperlinks after the Chat.

Dr. Scott Morton was Apple’s economic expert in the private litigation against Qualcomm. Mr. Melamed was senior vice president and general counsel of Intel from 2009 to 2014, and he advised Intel in the past regarding legal issues concerning some aspects of Qualcomm’s conduct.
And Mr. Barnett has presented at events sponsored by Qualcomm, but otherwise has no connection to any party in this litigation or related litigation.
Hal Singer: Doug, let’s talk about Qualcomm’s “no-license, no-chip policy” to set the stage. What is the traditional rubric under which antitrust assesses such conduct?
It is tying? It is bundling? Exclusive dealing? Are these two separate products? What chapter of a future antitrust treatise would one find this case?
Doug Melamed: It could be in a variety of sections—including tying, monopolization, or antitrust and IP—but I think the more important point is to understand the substance of the issue.
Qualcomm has monopoly power in chips. It ties its chips to licenses for its SEPs when used in either its chips or competitors' chips.
As with all such ties, the effect is to use some of its chip power to increase the price it can charge for the license.
Unlike tying, though, to the extent only SEPs are involved, it does not divert demand from substitutes for the tied licenses.
It might not increase the total price—chip plus license—for Qualcomm chips, but it directly increases the cost to the customer of competitors’ chips because it increases the price of the license.
Singer: I realize that conduct can straddle many bins, and that life is messy, but it helps our readers to know generally where this conduct fits.
Melamed: I understand, but analogies are usually imperfect. Qualcomm’s no license/no chips policy does not directly harm competition in any technology market.
But the effect of the policy—increased price for licenses for rivals’ chips—harms competition in the chip market.
The increased license price means either fewer chip sales by Qualcomm’s competitors or a reduced price of competitors’ chips to offset the artificial increase in the license price.
In effect, Qualcomm imposes a tax on rivals and thereby reduces rivals’ incentives for innovation and entrenches Qualcomm’s monopoly.
Although the factual impact takes some work to unpack, as a matter of law, it’s an easy case. It is an artificial contrivance that harms rivals to an existing monopoly.
Fiona Scott Morton: The no license/no chip policy is the method by which Qualcomm extracts monopoly profit.

Without the threat of withholding chips (which is the same as the threat of no revenue on those handsets, namely a large amount of money), Qualcomm could not force the payment of above-FRAND royalties.
Without that leverage, original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) would ask a court to determine FRAND. So that’s the conduct’s primary purpose.

However, the clever exclusionary feature of no license/no chip, which the court explains clearly, is that, at the same time, it puts a tax on rival chip makers because OEMs must pay the royalty even if they escape Qualcomm’s chip market power by buying from a rival.
Additionally, Qualcomm often sets a higher royalty if an OEM buys from a rival.
Singer: Jonathan, Fiona and Doug liken Qualcomm’s conduct to a tax on rival chip makers. Is tax the proper analytical lens?
Jonathan Barnett: First, I think the use of the "tax" rhetoric is unhelpful to an objective antitrust analysis.
As the 1995 IP Guidelines made clear, the royalty negotiated by the IP holder simply reflects the price the market is willing to pay for its good, as with any other goods or services market.
Unless it is argued that Qualcomm’s SEPs are invalid or not infringed, then Qualcomm is entitled to extract a royalty with respect to all products and services to which the technology pertains.
This is not an “artificial increase” in the license price: it is the fee negotiated for using the patented systems-level technology that is not embodied in the physical chipset.
Second, I think it is important to go back to the structured framework courts have developed to analyze tying claims.

Even if we grant the first two prongs of the traditional test (market power + separate products), I don't see how the evidence, plus the broader empirical literature, plausibly supports any harm to competition in the market more generally.
To the contrary. This is a market in which adoption has been rapid, output has expanded, and prices adjusted for quality has declined.
So that seems to preserve the presumption that tying in general is either innocuous or procompetitive.
Scott Morton: Claiming that tech markets move fast, and therefore there is no harm, is a policy that completely insulates tech companies from antitrust liability because of secular price declines.
There could be no LCD cartel by this reasoning, because the prices of those screens fell during the collusive period.
This is contrary to fact—but follows from the logic above. How about PC prices falling while there was collusion in DRAM, LCD screens, and monopolization by the Microsoft OS?

All that conduct is given a pass because prices were falling? And by the way, "tax" is not rhetoric. It is the technical term used by economists to describe a price addition on a product made by someone else.

Melamed: The basic problem with what Jonathan is saying is that he overlooks that the royalty for the SEPs when used in rivals' chips is not a market royalty, but instead one artificially increased by use of Qualcomm’s market power in chips.
Scott Morton: You have to be able to identify the but-for world to make any point like this and be taken seriously.
What would technology have been like if Qualcomm had faced serious competition for the last 10 years?
Melamed: There is another problem, too, which is that royalties determined after infringement, which is the case here, are never just market royalties.
They are settlements of legal disputes in the shadow of litigation.

Barnett: Outside explicit price fixing, almost any antitrust fact pattern gives rise to multiple interpretations, so sound public policy recommends that we select the most plausible interpretation given available evidence and taking into account the costs of false-positive versus false-negative errors.

In general, modern courts have tended to start with a presumption of zero liability in the case of tying, given the wealth of procompetitive explanations and have been especially reluctant to undo ties in fast moving technology markets (see the Microsoft court's decision not to order the unbundling of Internet Explorer from the Microsoft operating system).

Given the scope of the remedy in this case, which would essentially rewrite the entire licensing infrastructure in which the market has thrived for several decades and would therefore give rise to large social costs if the court got it wrong, I think the evidence of expanding output, falling price, and unimpeded innovation should give pause to fixing what doesn't seem to be broken.

Scott Morton: As I said before, there is no such evidence unless you can specify a counterfactual. Additionally, this phrase "then it is entitled to extract a royalty with respect to all products and services to which the technology pertains" ignores the voluntary FRAND commitment Qualcomm made.
That limits its royalty and thereby renders it unnecessary to use chip leverage because a court will happily enforce FRAND.
I have never heard of the presumption you claim either.
Melamed: What is the "most plausible interpretation" depends on the facts, and the 233-page opinion makes clear what the facts are here.
Singer: Doug, quick legal question: If the conduct is styled as a tie-in, is there any legal requirement that plaintiff show competitive effects?
Or are tie-ins treated differently? Jonathan seems to suggest that the effects element is missing here.
Melamed: I think competitive effects do have to be shown. But foreclosure in the tied product market is not necessary, as we learned in Microsoft.
Here, as in Microsoft, the harm is to competition in the tying product market—that is, the chip market.
Singer: Changing subjects. Fiona, why intervene in markets where buyers and sellers have significant market power?
Doesn’t economic theory predict that the offsetting buyer/seller power could result in competitive prices for the input here?
Perhaps some of Qualcomm’s customers lack buying power, but certainly Apple must have significant buying power in the chip market.
My family alone has 17 Apple devices! I can just hear the Chicago School crowd chanting “Let the magical market fairies resolve things!”
Scott Morton: You hear this quite a bit in the healthcare context: “since the hospitals have merged and have bargaining power, we should let insurers merge.”
This is nuts to me. Two wrongs do not make a right, as the saying goes. My view is that policy and enforcement should seek to keep all markets free of anticompetitive conduct.
Moreover, many buyers of chips do not have the bargaining power of Apple, so your plan does not help them at all, whereas competition in chips would.

Singer: I don't know if I have any plan beyond where I’m eating tonight, but my question (restated) is: Why can't Apple's countervailing buying power be counted on to push input prices back down to competitive levels?
Perhaps Qualcomm's selling power is special here, given the patent? Or the conduct?
Scott Morton: That's what the 233 pages of facts describe, why it was that no buyer was strong enough to defeat the anticompetitive scheme.
However, as I said already, supposing one buyer could defeat it, but all the others paid higher prices, why would we think that is a victory compared to enforcing so the entire market is competitive?
Singer: That's a great point, and why I think the smaller OEMs make for a better fact pattern. I was thinking about Apple's claim against Qualcomm in particular.
Melamed: Most phone makers do not have market power, and even buyers with market power are not guardians of the public interest.
They can be given a share of monopoly rents to, for example, agree to anticompetitive exclusive dealing, as was the case here
Barnett: I think it is important to appreciate the bargaining power on each side in the SEP smartphone market.
Currently Apple captures approximately 40% of the retail price on the iPhone while most estimates give all IP licensors collectively about 5%.
So that should give some caution in adopting the view that an individual SEP licensor is ever in a position to dictate terms to a licensee.

Additionally, keep in mind that, by the time licensing negotiations commence, the upstream R&D firm has already sunk billions into technology that it has yet to monetize and may not even have achieved adoption in the market.

The same is not true of the licensees that have not borne comparable costs and risks at that stage. I think that the rebates and incentive payments that the opinion documents being offered at least to large licensees reflects this bargaining dynamic, which is far from one sided.
It is also consistent with the trade literature that notes that large licensees are often able to substantially reduce "nominal" royalty rates through cross licensing and other terms.
Scott Morton: Every product is different, so comparing the cost of IP to the gross margin of the finished good and expecting that to be some constant across products does not make sense.
There are a wide variety of business models. Second, in the US, we don't pay innovators before they have invented something that a buyer decides is useful.

That's why innovation is risky! To say to Qualcomm, “Sure we'll promise to license and use everything you invent for 5% of the handset without knowing whether or not it's any good” is an odd social contract and not one that provides good incentives for useful innovation.

Melamed: Even if we assume, counterfactually, a bilateral monopoly, the equilibrium price would in all likelihood still be supra-competitive, and the no license/no chip policy enables Qualcomm to allocate some of its market power in chips to the license by increasing the nominal price of the license.
It is that price increase that imposes a cost burden on rival chip makers.

Singer: Jonathan, you argue in a recent op-ed that Judge Koh’s decision, if upheld, would “endanger a patent-based licensing model that has supported innovation across several generations of wireless communications technology.”

You go on to explain that the ruling would disadvantage firms that operate under licensing-based business models “in which R&D is monetized externally and disseminated broadly,” and would favor “integrated business models in which R&D is monetized internally and not disseminated at all.”
Jonathan, which U.S. firms besides Qualcomm operate under a patent-based licensing model? How important are these firms that “monetize R&D externally” to the U.S. economy?
And wouldn’t a detractor say that the decision would only expose such firms if they also (1) had monopoly power and (2) were found to have violated the antitrust laws?

Barnett: At the risk of unintentional omission, I think it is widely acknowledged that there are four firms in the current market that have made the key technological contributions to the 3G and 4G wireless markets—ARM, Qualcomm, Nokia and Ericsson.

Going back to 2G/GSM, we would add Motorola. These upstream firms rely to varying extents on being able to license IP to downstream users (equipment makers and telecom carriers) and, in the case of nonpayment, to enforce those licenses and patents in court.

ARM (which licenses to chip design firms) and Qualcomm (which licenses to OEMs) adopt the “purest” forms of this model because they are not integrated (ARM), or are not integrated substantially (Qualcomm), into downstream production, assembly and distribution.

What I intended to suggest in the language you quoted is that, in a world in which licensing relationships are easily subject to legal challenge (how will an IP licensor ever know what a court will deem to be a “fair and reasonable” royalty rate?) and IP owners generally cannot secure an injunction (under the case law that has developed in the past decade or so), the viability of this model for privately funding R&D is placed at risk.

That doesn’t mean innovation would come to a halt. It means that firms will be compelled to monetize R&D by embedding that technology in hardware, software or other goods that are not as exposed to expropriation.
That’s Intel’s strategy with the microprocessor, which is not licensed to anyone, as well as Apple’s strategy with iOS, which is again not licensed to anyone.

Effectively forcing all firms to adopt an Intel-like strategy on chips and an Apple-like strategy on the operating system is a potential efficiency loss because it raises entry costs (since firms must innovate plus embed the innovation in a “tangible” product) and potentially limits OEMs’ access to technology inputs since firms that integrate downstream into the device markets are likely to have little incentive to license out their innovations.
Scott Morton: They are discussing Qualcomm at the OECD right now too!
Singer: Fiona, I need you to close your other browser and focus on the Chat.
Scott Morton: I am confused as to why Qualcomm would be worse off—under its own theory of the case—if it went to a court and asked the court to determine FRAND and put a fair value on its technology.
The company has said repeatedly it has great technology, so it should not be afraid of that scrutiny.
FRAND policies are voluntary, and SSO members know that disputes will be resolved by courts—and they could have picked a different scheme if they thought courts were bad at determining FRAND.
Likewise, if Qualcomm’s chips are better due to its own research skill, Qualcomm may have market power achieved on the merits and can charge a premium for those chips.

I am not seeing how the business model is harmed by being unable to leverage chip supply to force a higher royalty—unless the royalty was not justified by the technology and was above a competitive rate to begin with.
Moreover, since we don't do much manufacturing in the US anymore, everything is imported, and therefore subject to possible ITC exclusion orders.
That seems like a very powerful threat for IP holders, indeed, one that Qualcomm tried using against Apple (twice).
Melamed: Once again, I prefer to focus on facts. First, this case was based on no license/no chip, which is about misuse of market power in chips.
It is not an attack on non-practicing entity business models. Nor does it mean that "licensing relationships are easily subject to legal challenge."
Qualcomm has monopoly power in chips, and its unlawful conduct was specific to its circumstances.

Barnett: As a practical matter, in a world in which (1) SEP owners have no credible injunction threats against infringers, (2) infringers generally have sufficient resources to litigate indefinitely, and (3) courts have no added-value expertise in evaluating the appropriate royalty rate, Qualcomm would have a substantially reduced expectation in being able to enforce negotiated licenses even if those were set at "appropriate" rates since they would inevitably be challenged in court.
The SEP infringement litigation makes clear that courts have no adequate methodology by which to evaluate royalty rates absent a competitive benchmark.
In that world, an R&D intensive firm would adapt by moving away from licensing and extracting value through the direct sale of products and services.
That limits access to technology inputs for downstream firms without comparable R&D capacities.
Melamed: There are fundamental problems with the trope about harming welfare by reducing the monopolist’s incentives.

It is wrong, or at least very overstated, as a factual matter for a number of reasons. Perhaps more important, it focuses just on the monopolist and overlooks the ultimate issue, which is innovation in the market as a whole.
When monopolists use their power to impede rivals, they reduce incentives for innovation by actual and potential rivals and by the market as a whole.
Scott Morton: Qualcomm could always suggest the establishment of a specialized arbitrator that was quick and inexpensive for FRAND disputes.
An SSO could adopt such a method for dispute resolution if Qualcomm thinks courts are so terrible at determining FRAND.
Carl Shapiro and I have a paper, and a little model, demonstrating Doug’s point above.

Melamed: I have not seen a lot of endless litigation by implementers. And if Qualcomm wanted to prevent that, it could license the whole market by licensing a handful of chip makers, instead of choosing to license downstream for the purpose, as found by Judge Koh, of gaining more licensing revenues.

Barnett: The specialized arbitration mechanism is a theoretical possibility and could be a constructive solution but, again, the SEP infringement litigation to date shows that courts look for comparable licenses to determine royalty rates.

Once any negotiated license can be challenged in court, and again without the ability to block infringers through injunction, the bargaining leverage shifts to downstream producers and the licensing market is distorted and no longer provides an accurate benchmark by which an arbitrator or court can determine patent value through comparable licenses.
The bargaining dynamic I described above, in which the IP provider has already sunk costs into R&D and sometimes has yet to monetize it, exacerbates this situation further.
Singer: Judge Koh’s opinion invokes Aspen Skiing, which established the conditions under which a firm must deal with its rivals.

Although its reach has been marginalized by subsequent decisions such as Trinko, Aspen’s duty to deal turned on evidence of defendant’s terminating a “voluntary and profitable course of dealing” with its rivals and doing so without “valid business reasons”.

As a basis of liability, Judge Koh’s opinion finds a course-of-dealing shift by Qualcomm, which previously licensed its SEP to modem chip suppliers, citing Qualcomm exchanges with the IRS from 2012 (page 127) and internal emails in 1999 (page 137).
Will this opinion breathe new life into Aspen? If so, are there any firms in the economy that are particularly vulnerable to stronger enforcement of refusals to deal with rivals?
Could this decision, for example, force Facebook to interoperate with a social media upstart?
Barnett: Personally, I found this to be the weakest part of the opinion because it essentially misapplies Supreme Court precedent.

Aspen Skiing has been drastically narrowed in subsequent Supreme Court rulings (the Court placed it “at the outer boundary” of antitrust law in Trinko), which suggests that it should be confined to its facts.

The facts as determined by the district court do not fit into that narrow window. According to those findings, Qualcomm apparently licensed certain chip manufacturers about 20 years ago and then moved to device-level licensing.
That hardly fits the facts of Aspen Skiing, in which two ski operators were profitably engaged in an uninterrupted joint venture over the course of more than a decade.
Additionally, Aspen Skiing requires that the defendant terminate the cooperative relationship without “valid business reasons.”

The court’s opinion identifies that business reason: it was more “lucrative” for Qualcomm to do so. It’s hard to imagine a more legitimate business justification (unless we adopt discredited Alcoa-type reasoning that a monopolist monopolizes simply by expanding output to meet market demand).

This too distinguishes the facts from Aspen Skiing, in which the court imposed a duty to deal in part because the defendant essentially threw money away by refusing cash-equivalent ticket vouchers that were presented by the terminated operator’s customers.

Melamed: Aspen was expressly not overruled by Trinko, so it does not need new life. The key point is that the refusal to license at the chip level, where Qualcomm could not use its market power to coerce artificially increased license royalties, pushed all licensing down to the device level, and thus acted in aid of Qualcomm’s unlawful no license/no chips policy.
This case did not involve a standalone refusal to deal, such as that at issue in Trinko.
Scott Morton: Jonathan, there is no FRAND commitment in your example. This case is stronger than Aspen for that reason.
Furthermore, when “lucrative” reflects monopoly profit acquired through the illegal conduct, it is not a “valid business reason.”
Barnett: The FRAND commitment does add a new factor. However, courts have generally deemed it a contractual agreement (under third-party beneficiary doctrine).
For purposes of appeal, I understand that the Judge's opinion relied on Aspen in order to impose a duty to deal independent of any contractual obligation.
That is in part why the implications of the decision on this point are broader than might otherwise have been the case.
Melamed: I agree that Judge Koh’s reliance on the earlier sales was weak, but I think the criticism conflates principle and evidence.

The principle is that a refusal to deal that entails a profit sacrifice—that is, that departs from the most valuable use of the asset—is anticompetitive conduct (see my article in Berkeley Tech Law Journal).
It therefore is, or at least should be, illegal if it harms competition, as it did here. The problem, of course, is proving a profit sacrifice.

Prior dealing is often-needed evidence of that sacrifice and of the required terms of trade. But that evidence was not needed here because Qualcomm agreed to license on FRAND terms and thus demonstrated that such licensing, in exchange for inclusion of its patents in the standard, was profitable.
Scott Morton: Then there are two reasons Qualcomm must license! Both good.
Singer: In a fiery Wall Street Journal op-ed, FTC Commissioner Christine Wilson came out against her agency’s victory in the matter.

She wrote the judge “radically expanded a company’s legal obligation to help its competitors by reviving and extending a discredited Supreme Court case called Aspen Skiing v. Aspen Highlands Skiing (1985).”
She also claimed that the decision “contains no territorial limitations,” and thus affects contracts between Qualcomm and foreign buyers for products “sold to consumers living abroad.”
We’ve talked about Aspen already. Let’s focus on her second critique concerning geographical reach. Doug, is this a fair critique of the decision?
Melamed: No. Qualcomm sells chips in a global market to U.S. and foreign manufacturers. Harm to competition in that market, wherever the conduct takes place, harms the US.

Under those circumstances, a global remedy is needed to protect the United States, and such a remedy is entirely consistent with both well-established principles of international law and the Foreign Trade Antitrust Improvements Act of 1982, 15 U.S.C. § 6a, which governs extraterritorial application of US antitrust law.
By the way, I think Commissioner Wilson’s op-ed was very inappropriate. She is one of 5 FTC Commissioners, all appointed by President Trump.
As I see it, an FTC Commissioner can work with her colleagues to determine or change FTC conduct, and she can dissent from decisions with which she disagrees.
But having failed at that, she should not write an op-ed criticizing the agency and the court that agreed with it and asking a court of appeals to reverse it.
Imagine a district court judge writing such an op-ed about an opinion of another judge on the same court or an Associate AG asking a court to block a DOJ policy.
General principles of respect for process, institutions, and colleagues and predecessors should preclude such conduct.
Scott Morton: Many markets are now global and we have devised no system for determining which agency will be in charge of cases with a global dimension.
If Qualcomm wants to have a global contract for chips with Samsung, then it will have to comply with all the relevant antitrust laws and rulings in all the relevant jurisdictions.

It seems possible for Qualcomm to create US-only contracts if it feels that’s worthwhile. Of course, if a US court determines that FRAND is $0.10 for Qualcomm’s patents, then it is not clear why an OEM selling in Russia or Brazil would be willing to pay $10.
At some level, the increased transparency the decision requires may really be the problem for Qualcomm, not global contracts.
Barnett: I also don't see any legal issue on this point. I think Commissioner Wilson was perhaps just pointing out the far-reaching effects of the decision.

Singer: In the same op-ed, Commissioner Wilson also argues that unless the decision is overturned, “it invites the plaintiffs’ bar to file private antitrust suits against companies that decline to share their secret sauce—whether it’s a patent, an algorithm or an actual sauce recipe—with competitors.
Faced with this potential onslaught, a company understandably might question the value of investing in new assets and technologies.”
Is this a credible argument? What are the likely plaintiff follow-on cases, if any, made possible by this ruling?
And wouldn’t private plaintiffs seeking damages have to show a causal connection between the conduct and competitive effects, which apparently wasn’t done in this litigation?
Scott Morton: I don’t understand how selling a chip is giving away a “secret sauce.” Qualcomm has sold chips for a long time and that is one way it makes money.

Patents are public. Standards are public. Companies disclose their declared SEPs when licensing. FRAND rates are exactly chosen by a court to ensure fair payment to innovators and therefore preserve the incentive to innovate.

Barnett: On that point, Commissioner Wilson may have overdrawn the implications of the decision. But there is a possibility that such a broad application of Aspen Skiing, based on dated evidence of a past cooperative relationship with some firms (which the order then essentially extrapolates to a duty to deal to all similarly situated firms), could expose a large pool of firms to less than entirely robust “duty to deal” claims.

This too could discourage firms from pursuing licensing-based monetization models since, once a firm had entered into a relationship with a particular licensee, it may be exposed to legal liability if it ever sought to terminate that relationship (or, by the logic of the court’s opinion, declined to enter into a relationship with any similarly situated firm).

As Hal suggests, though, it would be expected that this risk would be tempered to the extent that a plaintiff would be required to show that any unilateral refusal to deal had an anticompetitive effect, as is typically the case in a rule of reason analysis.

Melamed: Commissioner Wilson seems to have in mind a demand by one firm for a license to a rival's trade secret (think Coke formula) or to patents that the firm does not what to license widely at any price.

But this case involves a firm whose core business is to license its patents to the entire industry. Moreover, the core of the case is the no license/no chips policy, not a standalone refusal to deal by a firm that has no interest in licensing its patents.
This case should not invite an “onslaught” of demands, and it will certainly not require future courts to relax the rules in very different circumstances.
Singer: Fiona, quick economic detour: Was it not possible to show a causal connection here between the challenged conduct and competitive effects?

For example, couldn't one show that Apple (or any other OEM) passed through a portion of the inflated royalty rate to consumers in the form of higher phone prices, and because the demand for phones is downward-sloping, we get output effects?

Scott Morton: Showing passthrough is econometrically hard work and technical. Here, the "CDMA adder" was the overcharge that Qualcomm explicitly adopted where it had market power and not where it didn't.
Per the opinion at 26: “Qualcomm planned to charge what the strategic plan called a ‘CDMA Adder’ of $4 on CDMA modem chips relative to comparable modem chips without CDMA capability.”
That was paid by the direct purchaser, which is the one antitrust laws protect. So I don't think any evidence on price effects is missing from the case.

Singer: Part of what Qualcomm did that was deemed anticompetitive, in addition to threatening Samsung’s chip supply and conditioning its terms (including a rebate on the royalty) on Samsung’s purchasing at least 85 percent of its chipsets from Qualcomm, was “paying to extinguish Samsung’s antitrust claims and to silence Samsung.”

The discussion begins at page 60 of the opinion. It cites to a 2018 Settlement Agreement in which Samsung agrees to release claims based on, among other things, “findings or conclusions articulated in . . .

(4) the ultimate decisions, settlement agreements or other dispositions of any of the cases brought against Qualcomm (or that contain counterclaims against Qualcomm) by the U.S. Federal Trade Commission . . .”
Judge Koh seems to be saying a monopolist cannot silence counterparties from interacting with antitrust enforcers.
Is this a novel finding, or has a settlement with a customer that waives future antitrust claims been recognized as being anticompetitive before?

In any event, is this good policy? Patent settlements that involve reverse payments in excess of certain benchmarks are deemed potentially anticompetitive, and the FTC’s Administrative Law Judge just found that 1-800’s trademark settlements with online lens suppliers were anticompetitive.
But I wasn’t aware of settlements to release antitrust claims could also be anticompetitive.
Scott Morton: To me this goes to the anticompetitive intent. Why would a party need to block a licensee from speaking to the antitrust authority if that party had not violated any antitrust laws?

Consider the similarity with pay for delay. In pay for delay the brand pays the generic not to let the court determine the patent is invalid, and in that way preserves monopoly power for longer, harming consumers.
In the case of Qualcomm, it pays an OEM to not let an agency determine the contracts are anticompetitive, and in that way preserves market power for longer, harming consumers.
Singer: Wow, wasn't expecting an answer from the token econ on the panel, but that was good!

Barnett: I take Fiona's point, but the language of the order seems to imply that any settlement by Qualcomm (or, by implication, any other IP licensor) entered into to resolve a dispute with an actual or prospective licensee would never be deemed free from legal challenge.

Without the types of qualifying factors that courts have introduced in the “pay-for-delay” cases to address those types of offsetting concerns, this would seem to discourage parties from ever settling litigation.
Without further modification, that rule cannot be sound policy.
Melamed: Settlements can be anticompetitive if they contain provisions requiring anticompetitive conduct, which is often the case with reverse payments settlements.
More generally, private claims can be settled by sharing monopoly rents and leave the illegal conduct of the defendant unchanged.

Therefore, Judge Koh is right not to just assume settlements are in the public interest. I understand the settlement agreement to require that Samsung will drop its claims against Qualcomm, including efforts to intervene in other proceedings, and its efforts affirmatively to persuade governments to bring cases against Qualcomm, but Samsung remains free to respond to government and other discovery requests.
As long as the settlement does not interfere with proceedings properly brought by others, it seems ok.
But it would be problematic if it prevented Samsung from bringing complaints about future conduct to the attention of government enforcers.
Singer: Fiona, as a testifying expert, I like to think (perhaps narcissistically) that economists are really really important in antitrust matters.
Despite my understanding of his prominent role at trial, I can’t find the FTC’s economic expert directly cited in the opinion.

Qualcomm’s economic experts also received little attention (and not the good kind). Instead, the court held that anticompetitive effects could be reasonably inferred from the conduct and liability turned largely on contemporaneous record evidence.
Given that so much of what testifying experts do in antitrust litigation is connect the conduct empirically to competitive effects, did economists play an important role in the case?
Where would I find their influence in the opinion? And if more courts go this route, will it permanently dampen the demand—shudder at the thought—for testifying economic experts?
Scott Morton: I disagree entirely with your premise. The three Qualcomm economists, Tasneem Chipty, Aviv Nevo, and my own Dean at Yale, Ted Snyder, were all found unreliable by the judge.
Carl Shapiro was not mentioned by name; instead the court adopted his economic opinions throughout the decision.
The court cites Professor Greg Mankiw’s economics textbook for an explanation of the tax on rivals; the court carries out a hypothetical monopolist test to determine Qualcomm has market power.
These are economic concepts that the judge learned from the FTC economist. It is very difficult, in my view, to get to the right answer in an antitrust case without good economics.
Singer: Disagreeing with the premise, eh? Perhaps you've been deposed a few times?
Scott Morton: And for a witness, having the court simply adopt your words, rather than quoting you, is fantastic.
A total win. The strength of the government's witness shows up in the narrative connecting the 233 pages of facts.
Singer: I need pinpoints, Fiona! See generally’s are frowned upon in this shop.
Melamed: Judge Koh understood the arguments made by the FTC's economists. Their job was to help her understand the facts.
It appears that they succeeded. It is possible she would have come to the same conclusion without the economists, but that is speculation.
She needed to explain why she disagreed with Qualcomm’s economists. She had no comparable need to comment specifically on the FTC's economists.
Singer: Jonathan? Did this decision need more cowbell aka MOAR econs?

Barnett: I agree that economists are vital to sound antitrust analysis and adjudication. But I don't feel that the court in this case gave due consideration to the economic analysis on either side, which does not give a great deal of confidence in the substantive outcome.

It's surprising that the court did not assess the strength of the government’s key expert witness and, in a single sentence I believe, essentially dismissed the testimony of the defendant’s key expert witness.

Yet the opinion has no trouble relying on and describes at length the obviously conflicted testimony of producer/licensees, such as Samsung, Huawei and others, who unsurprisingly allege that Qualcomm’s royalties are “too high.”

The district court’s failure to engage with the economic testimony in this case compares unfavorably with the district court’s thorough examination of the economic testimony in US v. ATT et al (Time Warner merger), independent of whether or not the substantive outcome in that case was correct.
Melamed: I am tempted to ask Jonathan what he thinks of the Supreme Court majority's attention to the facts in Amex.
Singer: Hold up, I’ve got my realtor on the line. Are you folks saying testifying experts need not liquidate their second homes in light of this decision?
Melamed: If it's a beach house, you have other reasons to sell.

Singer: My wife wants me to get rid of it in any event. Moving on. Judge Koh held that plaintiffs did not need to causally connect Qualcomm’s licensing practices with competitive effects with direct evidence, because Microsoft, holds that a court can infer causation from conduct generally (at 205): “Where the government is a plaintiff, the Court may “infer ‘causation’ from the fact that a defendant has engaged in anticompetitive conduct that ‘reasonably appear[s] capable of making a significant contribution to . . .

maintaining monopoly power.” Microsoft, 253 F.3d at 79 (citation omitted).” As Jonathan points out in his op-ed, however, the D.C. Circuit also stated in Microsoft that, “when using such an ‘edentulous’ standard for finding liability, it would be inappropriate to order the most extensive equitable remedies ‘[a]bsent some measure of confidence that there has been an actual loss to competition.’”
First, I had to look up “edentulous,” which means lacking teeth. Second, does this mean that Judge Koh’s decision on remedies is in tension with Microsoft?
Scott Morton: I don’t really understand why we think the opinion does not connect licensing practices with competitive effects.

The “CDMA adder” is a considerable price premium; Qualcomm has market power in chips so it is able to impose the adder; the documentary evidence explained how Qualcomm obtained market power in chips with its exclusive contracts, loyalty rebates, and no license/no chip; Qualcomm’s documents further show that these policies were designed to keep entrants out and extract profit.

Barnett: I find this to be an especially troubling part of the opinion. Typically, Section 2 findings of liability rest on objective evidence of effect (most obviously, price), which may then be supplemented by evidence of intent.
Consider the Apple e-books case: there was evidence of intent but there was powerful evidence of a price effect in the e-book bestseller market.
In this case, there is no objective evidence of effect, so the court relies almost entirely on subjective evidence of intent.
But subjective evidence is often unreliable since businesspersons often use language that is not necessarily indicative of anticompetitive intent in the antitrust sense.

I don’t think this intent-based approach is consistent with Section 2 jurisprudence generally (compare the demanding probative threshold set by the Supreme Court in the recent Amex decision), and could lead to lots of false positives if this approach were widely adopted.
Singer: Not to mention the reduction in the demand for econs!
Melamed: The theory of this case, like Microsoft, was that the anticompetitive conduct entrenched Qualcomm’s chip monopoly.
As in Microsoft, directional or probabilistic harm is enough and there is no need to prove a but-for world and compare it to the actual world.
Remedies serve a variety of purposes. The divestiture remedy in Microsoft was intended to restore competition, and the court held it was excessive given weak proof of actual harm.
The remedies ordered by Judge Koh are for the different purposes of terminating the unlawful conduct and preventing its recurrence.
The concerns of the Microsoft court are not applicable.
Barnett: I think the reasons that led the DC appeals court in Microsoft to reject divestiture pertain here.
While the order is not strictly speaking structural, the effects are -- it would require a renegotiation of potentially every OEM license and the negotiation of new licenses with chip makers.
For a remedy of that scope, the language in the Microsoft case suggests that an especially strong showing of harm is required.
Singer: Relatedly, Judge Koh appears to get to competitive effects indirectly via a high foreclosure share, by applying the factors from ZF Meritor.

In particular, Qualcomm’s exclusive arrangement were found to have “shrunk rivals’ sales and foreclosed its rivals from the positive network effects of working with Apple, which the Court discusses below.
In so doing, Qualcomm maintained the monopoly power in the CDMA and premium LTE modem chip markets that Qualcomm has used to sustain QTL’s unreasonably high royalty rates.”
(at 141) Under what conditions can a plaintiff establish anticompetitive effects without direct evidence linking the conduct to higher prices or lower output or reduced quality?
Is the “effects-free” path limited to exclusive dealing arrangements, or could foreclosure achieved via (say) self-dealing or self-preferencing also be subject to this standard?

(This is a good time to plug Fiona and Doug’s new piece on the challenges in applying antitrust to digital platforms, which notes the difficulty in observing competitive effects when they manifest as innovation harms.)
And is this path only available to agencies or private parties seeking injunctive relief?

Melamed: This is not "effects free" liability. The court used traditional analysis to infer harm to rivals from substantial foreclosure share (as did the court in Microsoft) and, at least in the Apple agreement, found harm to competition.

Singer: I certainly didn’t mean “econ free” liability. I simply intend to convey that there is no direct evidence—for example, an econometric model linking the conduct causally with an output or price effect.
Scott Morton: Once again, a simple economic model and Qualcomm’s documents show directly that its practices were designed to create market power, and did so.

The evidence is so plain that the FTC did not need an “econometric model.” Sometimes lawyers get confused that the strength of economic evidence is related to the number of equations or Greek letters used, but this is not how its measured!

Barnett: I think this is one of the few potentially reasonable parts of the opinion because the court uses the existing analytical framework in the case law for analyzing an exclusive dealing arrangement based on actual or potential foreclosure effects.
Nonetheless I’m not sure the court shows the coercion element that is typically required to find an exclusive dealing arrangement unlawful.

Apple obviously exercised considerable bargaining power given its dominant position in the branded retail market, which appears to be reflected by the fact that it was Qualcomm that paid Apple for exclusivity, both through the incentive payments and rebates.

Melamed: The incentive payments are a way of sharing monopoly rents. That is enough for liability. There was no marketwide output effect proven as to the past, but again this is a monopoly maintenance case not a monopoly creation case.
Singer: The opinion found offense in Qualcomm’s royalties being set as a percentage of the value of the end-product, in this case, cellphones.
Judge Koh ruled that such a formula was inconsistent with federal patent law, and that Qualcomm’s royalty rates should be based instead on the value of specific patented parts.
But how can the value of input be fully de-linked to the value of the output in which the input is used.
Marshall’s laws of derived demand tell us how the elasticity of demand for an input is connected to the elasticity of demand for the final good.
Does anyone have ideas as to how Qualcomm could achieve this de-linking?

Barnett: I don't think it’s feasible, which is shown by the fact that the wireless market does not follow this practice and courts have failed when attempting to artificially engineer component level licensing in infringement litigation.

Device-level licensing is virtually universal among IP licensors in the smartphone/wireless market. Absent a conspiracy among the 20 IP licensors who account for approximately 80% of all SEPs in the 4G market, that strongly suggests that it is efficient.

There are several rationales for device-level licensing: (1) it is more efficient to extract value at a single point on the supply chain, (2) it is more efficient to do so at the point of sale, at which point customer demand (and therefore market valuation) is revealed, (3) it shifts to the supplier part of the risk of market failure, which actually benefits producers, and (4) it minimizes the risk of double marginalization (royalty stacking).

Not coincidentally, reasons (1)-(3) explain why a star actor’s variable compensation on a movie is computed based on a percentage of the box office, so the logic probably applies quite generally across IP markets.
Barnett: That was Hollywood jargon. Lived too long in LA.
Scott Morton: This is a place where economists part company with most others. The competitive price for Qualcomm’s SEPs at any moment in time is a number, a dollar number.
Because I am a skilled arithmetician ( ;-) ) I can generate that same number by expressing it as a percentage of a chip or a percentage of a phone–all I have to do is vary the percentage.
For example, if a court determines that the correct royalty is $.50, that could be 2.5% of a $20 chip or it could be 0.1% of a $500 handset.
There is no reason the percentage rate needs to stay the same when moving between the handset and the chip.
Useful technology should be paid what it is worth in order to generate incentives for innovation. Imagine I had invented a fantastic new corkscrew design and I licensed it for $20 a unit.
The fact that that the entire production cost of the corkscrew is $1 does not prevent my idea from being worth $20 and the percentage royalty being 2000%.
Melamed: The theory about derived demand would suggest that it makes no difference, but there is abundant evidence that it matters a great deal.

In essence, by "anchoring" the fact-finder in the much, much greater value of the phone (compared to the chip component), the patent holder can manipulate the fact-finder to determine an inflated value for the patent.
That is why patent law has moved toward using the smallest saleable unit (here, the chip) as the base on which to determine the royalty.

Barnett: Patent law has generally only mandated use of the smallest saleable unit (in multi-component products) as the royalty base in jury trials where there are concerns that jury members will not appreciate that a small royalty on an entire product royalty base is economically equivalent to a larger royalty on a component-level royalty base.
Those sophistication concerns do not generally apply outside that context (as in a business negotiation).
Accordingly, the Federal Circuit has specifically rejected any substantive rule that courts in general must determine reasonable royalties based on the smallest saleable component.
Singer: Fiona, in proving liability, economists typically show a change in pricing that can be linked to a change in market power or foreclosure.

It appears that Qualcomm has charged the same royalty rate (approximately five percent of the value of the phones, but subject to royalty caps and rebates) since its inception, which renders such proof impossible.

Here Qualcomm’s percentage rate was deemed excessive, not because Qualcomm charged a higher fee with more market power or foreclosure, but instead because Qualcomm’s contribution to phone value allegedly declined relative to other inputs in the phone (e.g., the operating system, software, applications, and design).
What do we make of Qualcomm’s constant royalty share? Is Qualcomm’s constant royalty rate consistent with the exercise of monopoly?

Scott Morton: Yes. If one thought that FRAND was being followed and therefore the royalty reflected the value of the SEPs, and over time Qualcomm’s share of SEPs declines, its most critical patents expire, and the handset includes a lot of valuable technology unrelated to the communication capability, you would expect the royalty rate to be declining over time.
Even if Qualcomm purchases more LTE patents in one year for example, then after the purchase, the competitive royalty rate would rise.
Instead, we see a constant 5% announced as the “FRAND rate.” That simply cannot be the market price for 30 years.
Barnett: There are several efficiency explanations for the constant rate (subject to a fixed-dollar cap per device).

Here’s one. Start with the observation that SEP licenses are typically executed for long periods of time (10 to 15 years) so the parties have agreed from the outset to a fixed percentage (subject to a dollar ceiling per device) throughout the life of the standard.

If QCOM has market power, it may be asked why it did not preserve latitude to raise the rate over time, which would have enabled it to exploit “producer lock-in” as adoption expanded, network effects went into operation and market value increased.
A plausible answer is that committing to a long-term fixed rate provides adopters with assurance that royalty rates would remain constant over the course of a technology’s lifetime.

The implicit royalty cap enables QCOM to commit against holdup and induces producers to invest in the technology, which in turn seeds adoption by consumers, generates a broad sales base from which the IP licensor can extract royalties, and enables the IP licensor to accrue reputational capital that it can deploy to induce adoption when it launches the next iteration of the technology standard (3G, 4G and so on).

Scott Morton: But the court explains that the 5% “royalty cap” is the holdup. The FRAND commitment gives device makers assurance they are not being over-charged and due to the expiration of patents, royalties will naturally decline over time.

Singer: Does the consumer-welfare lens of antitrust cause courts tend to overweight the welfare of distributors such as Apple, who serve as proxies for end users, and underweight the welfare of input providers?
It seems like any advantage for platforms or distributors, even one acquired via merger, that knocks down the price of an input is recognized as a “win” for customers.
Antitrust scholars Herbert Hovenkamp and Ioana Marinescu write that “To the best of our knowledge no couurt has ever condemned a merger because of its anticompetitive effects in labor markets.”
Indeed, one dissenting judge (who will go unnamed) in a health insurance merger would have found proof of reduced provider payments an adequate efficiency defense.
Does antitrust law have a bias against input providers and innovators generally? And does Qualcomm fit this pattern?
Melamed: There is nothing in the consumer welfare standard that disadvantages input suppliers. See my article with Nicolas Petit in Review of Industrial Organization.
In any event, this case was about violations by a seller—Qualcomm—and was thus squarely within antitrust’s sweet spot.
Scott Morton: Symmetry is an interesting idea. I wonder if the folks arguing for Qualcomm would support a minimum wage of $75 rather than $7.50?

The best paper on this topic is by Hemphill and Rose in last year’s Yale Law Journal explaining that if the bargaining power is obtained through anticompetitive conduct, then the lower prices are not efficiencies, but harms.
Competitive markets are best served when inputs are purchased at competitive prices. Allocative efficiency is preserved in that case, but also incentives to invest.
If we drive down the pay of doctors in Anthem Cigna, then doctors will exit those regions and that harms consumers.
Singer: Let’s move to remedies. Judge Koh ordered that Qualcomm renegotiate its terms with customers at “fair and reasonable” rates.
I’m trying to figure out how that would work in practice. The opinion suggests ideas such as comparing royalties in markets where Qualcomm is dominant from those where it is not.
Do we get to exploit sufficient variations in Qualcomm’s royalty rates here? Did the FTC’s experts offer up benchmarks by which Qualcomm’s royalties could be measured on grounds of reasonableness?
Is there a way to index Qualcomm’s royalty to the comparative strength of its patent position in the standard-essential-patent bundle?
How does one get at the but-for royalty in practice—that is, the access fee that Qualcomm would charge for its SEPs absent any threat to pull its chips?
Does the recent sequence of U.S. and European SEP infringement litigations, which address the determination of “FRAND-compliant” royalties for SEPs, give us any insight on this point?
Scott Morton: Determining FRAND is not unusual now. We have several court decisions that have carried out that task and Qualcomm and OEMs just need to get started.
The FTC was not being a rate setting agency—remember the above FRAND rate is the way Qualcomm extracts its market power, not the anticompetitive tactics the FTC identified.
Barnett: Courts have wrestled with this question in SEP infringement litigation over the past few years.
The results are not encouraging. Reasonable royalties are typically determined in patent law based on a hypothetical negotiation between a willing licensor and licensee.
To do so, courts typically rely heavily on evidence from comparable licenses. To my knowledge, in all but one SEP litigation so far in the U.S., U.K. and EU, courts have followed this principle.

But there’s a mismatch problem between judicial and market valuation. While courts seek to apportion the value of individual patents on a strictly “money” basis for damages purposes, markets typically engage in device-level portfolio licensing and trade off price and non-price terms.
This tends to result in somewhat arbitrary valuation outcomes in court given the absence of any straightforward market benchmark.

If the court’s order were implemented in this case, this problem would be repeated many times over given the number of licensees and potential appeals to a court or arbitrator in the case of deadlock.
Singer: Any final thoughts? What do you think happens on appeal?
Barnett: I think the case is especially vulnerable on Aspen Skiing. Otherwise hard to predict.
Melamed: I think the basic rulings on the no license/no chips policy and exclusive dealing will be affirmed.
The rest might be also, but I would not be surprised to see some revisions on those matters.
Scott Morton: I leave appeals predictions to the attorneys!
Singer: Well, thanks a zillion for taking the time! Let’s it call that a wrap. I think we’re going to break antitrust twitter when this posts.

query: Qualcomm's rivals in the chip industry
url2text: The European Commission has levied a fine of €997 Million, approximately $1.2 Billion, against U.S. chipmaker Qualcomm Inc. for violating antitrust laws in a series of deals with Apple by "abusing its market dominance in LTE baseband chipsets."

According to the European Union (EU), Qualcomm paid Apple billions of dollars to make the iPhone-maker exclusively use its 4G chips in all its iPhones and iPads, reducing competition from other competing manufacturers in the LTE baseband chip industry like Intel.

The European Commission launched an investigation in 2015, which revealed that Qualcomm abused its market dominance in LTE baseband chipsets and struck a deal with Apple in 2011, which meant the iPhone maker would have to repay Qualcomm if it decided to use a rival's chipsets until the end of 2016, hurting innovation in the chip sector.

The fine imposed on the chip maker is hefty, but won't hurt Qualcomm's bottom line significantly as it represents 4.9 percent of the company's turnover in 2017, according to the EU's antitrust commission.
Qualcomm said it 'strongly disagrees' with the European Commission's decision and will 'immediately appeal' it at the General Court of the European Union.
The company also believes its agreement with Apple does not violate European Union competition law.

The European Commission has levied a fine of €997 Million, approximately $1.2 Billion, against U.S. chipmaker Qualcomm Inc. for violating antitrust laws in a series of deals with Apple by "abusing its market dominance in LTE baseband chipsets."

According to the European Union (EU), Qualcomm paid Apple billions of dollars to make the iPhone-maker exclusively use its 4G chips in all its iPhones and iPads, reducing competition from other competing manufacturers in the LTE baseband chip industry like Intel.

The European Commission launched an investigation in 2015, which revealed that Qualcomm abused its market dominance in LTE baseband chipsets and struck a deal with Apple in 2011, which meant the iPhone maker would have to repay Qualcomm if it decided to use a rival's chipsets until the end of 2016, hurting innovation in the chip sector.
"This meant that no rival could effectively challenge Qualcomm in this market, no matter how good their products were.
This is illegal under EU antitrust rules and why we have taken today's decision," EU competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager said in a press statement.

Apple received payments from Qualcomm for approximately 5 years between 2011 and 2016. The company still uses Qualcomm components in its iPhones and iPads, but it began using Intel LTE modems in its iPhone 7 and 7 Plus devices after the agreement ended.

The fine imposed on the chip maker is hefty, but won't hurt Qualcomm's bottom line significantly as it represents 4.9 percent of the company's turnover in 2017, according to the EU's antitrust commission.
Qualcomm said it 'strongly disagrees' with the European Commission's decision and will 'immediately appeal' it at the General Court of the European Union.
The company also believes its agreement with Apple does not violate European Union competition law.
"We are confident this agreement did not violate EU competition rules or adversely affect market competition or European consumers," Qualcomm General Counsel Don Rosenberg said in a statement.

"We have a strong case for judicial review, and we will immediately commence that process."Not just one, Qualcomm is facing a patent fight with Apple over chip royalties, and simultaneously fending off a $100 billion hostile takeover from rival chipmaker Broadcom, but it rejected the bid last November, saying it 'dramatically undervalued' the company.
